story: The inscrutable Tory bigwig could be wanting to bring a vote to the people shortly after a No Deal Brexit. Heres the latest.Boris Johnson, elected last month by Conservative party members as Britains new Tory leader and PM, could trigger a general election.As of August , Coral is offering   odds on one taking place this year.Both PaddyPower and Betfair are offering  .William Hill is offering   odds, while Bet gives   chances.The entire race for Conservative Party leadership was centred around Brexit - Boris says that he will try to secure a better Brexit deal, but promises thatthis isnt possible he will crash out without one.His support for a no-deal Brexit has sent at least five MPs running.Boris may want to trigger a general election before Brexits  day time limit is up in order to secure a bigger parliamentary majority to get his deal through Parliament.Johnsons staunch leave stance - as opposed to Theresa Mays dithering over Brexit - could see him win votes from members of other parties gunning to leave.Despite it widely being parroted that a general election this year is inevitable, Boris has said he is against the idea of a snap election.Mr Johnson has ruled out having a general election before the UK leaves the EU which is currently set for October , .However, Bojo’s top aides are now saying they believe they could trigger a poll in September — evenRemainer MPs attempt to ­topple the Government.Labour’s health spokesman Jonathan Ashworth said that the NHS funding announcement raised speculation that an election could come “very soon”.With rumours of a General Election, bookies are offering odds on when the next one will take place.Below are the latest election odds given by bookmaker Coral as of August , :Boris could try and call a snap election at any time. He would have to pass a vote of MPs in the Commons first, however, thanks to the Fixed-Term Parliaments Act.Elections in this country take place on a Thursday.By law, Parliament is dissolved  working days before a General election.

title: gcse results day time resit exam
story: Heres all you need to know about the big day and how to prepare for it...GCSE results day is August , , for England and Wales.Pupils will be able to collect their results in the morning, usually at around am.Those waiting can also sign up to receive an email as soon as their results have been revealed.Schools will be able to see exam results on most examining boards systems by August  but they are for headteachers and exam officers eyes only.The government grading system altered students grades from A* to G to a numerical system from to .It is designed to give more dferentiation at the top end of the scale, with a grade  pitched above an A* in the old system – relatively few students will achieve these.A grade  is similar to an old grade C, representing the basic pass grade, while schools will also be measured on the proportion of pupils achieving a “strong pass” of five or above.If you have a grade  or below in exams like English and Maths, you will be expected to resit these GCSEs until you pass them in order to study at school or college.A grade  is roughly the same as an A grade, with universities and employers considering these to be very good grades, reported iNews.If a child has a sixth-form or college place pending, the exam board can re-mark papers as a priority.Those not waiting to move into further education can request a copy of the marked paper, or have a clerical check or review of the marking.English language and maths will take place in November .For other subjects the earliest available time to resit would be June , but check with the school as this ies.You cant just retake the exam that you didnt do well in, you have to retake all the exams that are part of that specic subject.They are now released from am on results day itself - August .The boundaries are published separately by inidual exam boards, and will be found on their websites below:In the lead-up to results day, parents can distract their children from the anxious countdown by doing simple things from the list weve compiled below.Parents will most likely have to fork out for their child to take the test again.The cost depends on the exam board but they are usually around £ per GCSE and it will be more expensive for those who require extra resources.However, some schools will pay for a teen to retake an exam.The Exam Results Helpline, delivered by the National Careers Service will be available from  August to provide additional support to studentsas they receive their exam results.The helpline will be available on    from am to pm  days a week. Calls are free from landlines and most mobile numbers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: avoid publicity paul hollywood ask oscar winning judi dench
story: All the drama in his le — the latest being dumped by girlfriend Summer Monteys-Fullam after asking her to sign a laughably self-important “gagging order” — is entirely of his own making.Yet, in an Instagram post richer than triple chocolate mousse, he seemingly blames her for the media attention they attract. He also adds that: “I prefer a quiet le away from the day job.” And the band played Believe It If You Like.To recap: Paul is a master baker who caught a lucky break after being booked to appear on what became TV juggernaut The Great British Bake Off.Back then he was happily married to we Alex and, outside of an occasional media interview to plug the show, his home le never made the headlines.A bit of work and no play made Paul a dull boy when it came to clickbait. Then he had a fling with fellow TV chef Marcela Valladolid and all hell broke loose.Sex sells. It always has. So does scandal, and cheating on your we with a younger woman fits firmly into both categories.When the fling ended, the admirably forgiving Alex took Paul back, but the marriage faltered again and he took up with a -year-old barmaid with a fondness for miniskirts and crop tops.What’s not to love for the hundreds of “paparazzo”who make a living from how many times their photo gets viewed online It’s not rocket science, is it  Earlier this year I spotted Judi Dench out supermarket shopping.Yes, that Judi Dench. Dame of the British Empire. Oscar winner. Recipient of more awards than Mr Hollywood’s had hot buns.And favoured guest of chatshow host Graham Norton. But there she was, browsing the aisles and totally unbothered by anyone.Why  Well, firstly, she wasn’t wilfully drawing attention to herself by radiating self-importance. And secondly, while she’s paid to be dramatic on screen, her le outside of it is anything but.Meaning that, in everyday le, her showbiz currency — the aforementioned “clickbait” — is, depending on how you view such things, blissfully low.But , say, she decided to dump her conservationist partner David Mills for a young barman from her local pub, a photo of her low-key shopping trip would be front-page news. Simple really.Aside from the marvellous Ms Dench, there are oodles of A- listers who live non-famous lives, popping to the supermarket or going for a low-key dinner — for example, not The Ivy et al — with loved ones.Occasionally, they might be spotted and photographed, but they just keep their head down and ignore it, accepting that it’s a small price to pay for the myriad other benefits fame brings.NDAsare now commonly used by celebrities to ensure the silence of, say, a nanny who will be privy to what happens behind closed doors — and that’s perhaps understandable.But asking a lover to sign on the dotted line when you’ve already been together two years is saying, in so many words: “I don’t trust you, but I want to carry on sleeping with you.”Who can blame Summer for telling him to stick it where the sun don’t shine Famous US basketball coach and mentor, John Wooden , once said: “Talent is God given Be humble. Fame is man-given Be grateful. Conceit is self-given Be careful.”Wise words that Mr Hollywoodwould do well to heed.WHATEVER you think of Boris Johnson’s politics, it can’t be denied that he’s working his King Ashurbanipal socks offas our new PM.Hospitals, factories, flood-hit towns – you name it, he’s popping up there to put a smile on everyone’s face and reassure them that everything is under control.He’s the frontman while the rest of the bandare putting in the hours at the studio, hopefully producing the hits. Time will tell.But suffice to say, he’s already shaping up to be the UK’s cheerleader – a feat the more reserved and aloof Theresa May never quite managed.WHEN asked about children, Prince Harry replied that he and we Meghan might have “two, maximum”.Fair enough, I thought. After all, she’s  now and,she’s lucky, Mother Nature might let her conceive one more before her womb shuts shop.But no, it seems the royal couple’s decision is to do with population growth, despite experts saying that, globally, the birthrate is shrinking and the real issue is how long we’re all living.So unless he’s planning to pack Granny off to Dignitas, there’s not much he can do about it. But I digress.Regarding royal babies and, in particular, Harry and Meghan’s sensitivity around their firstborn’s privacy, perhaps they should copy his cousin Zara.She and husband Mike Tindall have two daughters, Mia, five, and Lena, one. There’s no showboating or churlishness, they just give their daughters as normal a le as possible via picnics, getting muddy, painting faces and rough and tumble – as seen in thisdelightful photo of mischievous Mia hitching a ride on Dad’s back.They occasionally get photographed, but clearly accept that it’s just one of those things and don’t let it bother them. A parenting template to be admired, whoever you are.THE author Alex Elle once said: “I am very cautious of people whose actions don’t match their words.”In which case, let’s hope she wasn’t invited to the recent Google Camp party in Sicily which,you’re one of the self-regarding A-listers in attendance, was a high-minded gathering to discuss the issue of climate change.Or to the rest of us – a boondoggle for entitled fools. How  to describe an event attended by  of some of the world’s richest people who arrived on eco-unfriendly private jets and luxury yachts Oh, the unacknowledged irony. Meanwhile, Leona Lewis and ious other celebrities, who advocate gun control, happily took a shilling or three to attend the Austria-based party of Gaston Glock – one of the world’s most famous gun makers.But back to Google Camp where – and I can’t quite believe I’m writing this – residents and hotel guests near the archaeological site of Selinunte were told by police to avoid looking out of their windows to protect the privacy of the invited A-listers dining al fresco.The same slebs, one assumes, who regularly virtue signal their moral credentials by advocating a world without borders, where everyone should be treated the same . . . yada yada. If hypocrisy was a movie, they’d all be winning Oscars.SCHOOLBOY Jay Hughes, , was talking to a friend outside a chicken shop in South London when a van pulled up and three men armed with machetes jumped out.His friend ran off and escaped but Jay stood in the shop doorway, where -year-old Nyron Jean-Baptiste stabbed him before boasting, “I got one”, and leaving the scene.Jean-Baptiste has now been jailed for “le” – whatever that means these days – while poor Jay’s distraught mother Cindy has been condemned to a letime of painful loss.Another devastated mother, Linda Burke-Monerville, spoke last month about sending her remaining children back to Nigeria for safety after losing three of her sons to violent crime in the UK.New Home Secretary Priti Patel said this week that she is resolutely focused on restoring law and order to our streets via extra police officers with greater powers.Talk is cheap – particularly when uttered by the majority of politicians. Action is what we need. And fast. Let’s hope she delivers before too many more young lives are snuffed out so brutally.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no need to ditch traditional puds
story: More than a third of young diners have never eaten a spotted dick and a quarter have never had a slice of flan, according to a study.What’s more, a fth of Brits aged  to  have never tried Eton mess, banoffee pie or rhubarb crumble — and one in six last ate jelly and ice cream TEN years ago.Traditional puds celebrate seasonal ingredients and are a pleasure to make. In winter there is nothing quite as satisfying as a steaming jam roly-poly with custard.Trle, my favourite, dates back  years. The word originally meant a light dessert, literally “a nothing”.But many desserts are disappearing from our menus.It’s not just the unfortunate overtones of roly–poly and spotted dick that are putting people off.Today, sugar, eggs, dairy and bread are out of fashion. People are opting for healthier desserts. Trendy cafes serve raw, dairy-free cakes.But I have to say “healthy dessert” is possibly the most disappointing combination of two words in the entire English language.Perhaps millennials are scared about the calories from eating out because of the growing pressure to look good on social media. If that’s the case, it’s very sad. title: uk holds the best cards brexit
story: We were warned about this before the referendum and have been told almost continuously for the past three years a British recession is just around the corner. But things aren’t quite working out that way.While the UK economy is far from booming, it is holding up much better than those in the Eurozone. Figures released yesterday show Germany’s manufacturing sector contracted by . per cent in July and is now a shocking . per cent smaller than it was a year ago.Given the importance of manufacturing to the German economy, it is likely the whole economy is now heading for recession — a fate the country only narrowly avoided at the end of last year.In Italy, too, economic growth has ground to a halt again — after the country only just hauled itself out of last year’s recession. In France, growth in the past three months fell to . per cent.By contrast, our economy looks relatively perky, with growth of . per cent in the three months to May. Figures released on Monday showed a rebound in confidence in the dominant services sector.Of the large Eurozone countries, only Spain is currently outgrowing us — but Spain is still recovering after a very deep recession from which it emerged in . In common with Italy, the Spanish economy is still smaller than it was before the - banking crisis.Not that you will hear any of this from Remainers. Every time a car factory is earmarked for closure or a steelworks runs into problems, we hear no end of people saying, “We told you so”.All bad news in the UK economy is automatically attributed to Brexit — on the BBC, especially. What we don’t hear is that manufacturing industries, especially cars and steel, are suffering the same problems across Europe.Germany’s car industry is still reeling from the scandal of Volkswagen cheating in emissions tests by installing software to detect when a car was in test mode.On top of that comes the proposed switch from petrol and diesel to electric cars. Many motorists — myself included — have put off buying new vehicles because we don’t know what to get.We have been told new petrol and diesel cars will be banned from  and worry they might be taxed out of existence well before then. Yet electric cars are still prohibitively expensive and can’t travel nearly far enough between charges.As for the steel industry, all across Europe it is struggling to compete with cheap competition from China — especially since the trade war with the US forced Chinese exporters to search for new markets away from America.Of course,we end up with a No-Deal Brexit and tarfs are imposed on imports and exports between Britain and the EU, it will cause some disruption to trade. But it is wrong to assume Britain will come off worse. In truth, EU exporters have more to lose. Britain runs a huge trade deficit with the EU.In  we exported £billion worth of goods and services to other EU countries and imported £billion from them — a trade gap of £billion. Moreover, EU exports to Britain are concentrated in products that attract relatively high tarfs.Cars, for example, attract an EU import tarf of ten per cent. If Britain chooses to impose that levy in reverse after Brexit, it will cause further mayhem in the German car industry.We also have a high deficit in food — which under EU rules attracts average tarfs of  per cent. For dairy products, the average EU import tarf is  per cent. If our Government decides to impose this on imports from the EU, it will mean the end of quite a few French cheese producers.Of course, the EU can avoid damaging these export industries by agreeing to a trade deal with the UK — one that doesn’t include the hated Irish backstop.Nearly half of Irish food exports go to the UK. Irish exports to other EU countries would be deeply affected as so many rely on UK roads. If there are delays at ports, traffic between Ireland and the Continent will suffer twice over — once crossing the Irish Sea then crossing the English Channel.EU leaders want to punish Britain for voting to leave their sacred project. They fear thatBritain is seen to do well, other countries will want to leave. But playing hardball with Britain will do deep harm to their own export industries.Does German chancellor Angela Merkel want to suffer the wrath of her country’s car makers  Does French president Emmanuel Macron wish to anger winemakers already struggling with an economic downturn at home A hard Brexit could cost Denmark as much as one per cent in lost gross domestic product. Their former economy minister Simon Emil Ammitzboll calls Brexit “the most visible threat to the Danish economy”.Holland and Belgium calculate similar falls will hit their economies, with the Dutch losing ten billion euros by . In Spain, wages for unskilled youths are lower than they were in the late s. Youth unemployment is a huge problem. Even qualied youths face a lower annual salary than their counterparts a decade ago.The alternative to all this is for the EU to swallow a bit of pride and agree to keep free trade flowing, perhaps via a temporary deal while long-term arrangements are negotiated.It won’t take much. Just remove the backstop — really just an underhand way of trying to keep Britain in the straitjacket of EU regulations and trade barriers — and some kind of withdrawal agreement would almost certainly make it through the Commons.If not, then yes, British industry will suffer in some ways from No Deal. But the Eurozone economies already lagging behind will take the bigger hit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris playing hardball eu from outset
story: First, he’s making the threat of No Deal serious. With Theresa May, it never was. But so far he’s got everything right.He hasn’t got long to sort out a deal, the days are counting down. title: queen brexit trusts judgement british
story: But judging from what is going on in Westminster this week, it could just as easily refer to the Remainer MPs in Parliament, who appear to have taken leave of their senses.With Brexit Day rapidly approaching on October  — and a new Prime Minister who is committed to seeing it through — MPs who want to block Brexit are panicking so much that some are even contemplating dragging our -year-old Queen into this sorry saga.Labour’s shadow chancellor John McDonnell suggested this week that were Prime Minister Boris Johnson to lose a widely anticipated vote of no confidence next month, opposition leader, Jeremy Corbyn, would pay a visit to the Monarch.“I don’t want to drag the Queen into this”, said McDonnell, “but I would be sending Jeremy Corbyn in a cab to Buckingham Palace to say we’re taking over.”Nor is he the only one who is willing to break with convention and embroil Her Majesty in politics as they desperately work overtime to try to block our departure from the EU.Dominic Grieve, a Remainer Conservative MP who spent much of the past three years trying to block Brexit, has made similar noises, suggesting he too would be willing to drag our Queen into these dishonourable attempts to thwart the majority will.But the idea of involving the Monarch is completely at odds with Britain’s long-held political traditions.The reality is that ever since Charles I lost his head in the th Century, following the English Civil War, the head of state has remained strictly neutral with respect to political matters.This is why, for more than  years, the Queen has been careful to stay “above politics”, and helps to explain why she is so adored.The Queen’s public speeches and actions always rely on advice from ministers and, as constitutional experts have long made clear, one of her key unwritten rules is that she avoids party politics.Indeed, in  The Sun stunned Westminster with an exclusive story revealing how Her Majesty had, in private, spoken critically of the EU.A highly reliable political source was quoted as saying that people who heard a conversation “were left in no doubt at all about the Queen’s views on European integration”.Indeed, this is why younger, or new, members of the Royal Family should avoid making overtly political interventions.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex choosing to send political messages while guest-editing Vogue magazine, or giving barefoot speeches to global elites at a Google Camp focused on climate change was, at best, ill-advised.The role of the Royal Family is not to engage in “woke” virtue-signalling but to stand firmly above and apart from politics.The more “politicised” members of the Royal Family become, the more they undermine the Sovereign’s claim to be our neutral head of state.This is why, in , her Majesty made it abundantly clear that our country’s referendum on EU member-ship was: “A matter for the British people to decide.”And the people did make a decision. They voted to leave the EU. The only problem, as we have since discovered, is that many MPs don’t share the Queen’s trust in the judgment of the British people. Rather than respect the decision, they have sought to overturn it.Given their lack of respect for the British people, it is perhaps not surprising to see their total lack of respect for our Monarch and our long political traditions. It is not the job of hard-Left politicians or Remainer MPs to decide what the Queen should or should not do.The only person from whom the Queen can take constitutionally binding advice is the Prime Minister. Should Boris Johnson lose a vote of no confidence then the Queen will be advised by her outgoing Prime Minister about who can or cannot command the confidence of the House of Commons.Further, as Prime Minister, it would be up to Mr Johnson to advise the Queen on whether to give Royal Assent to a Bill passed by the Commons and Lords blocking a No-Deal Brexit. It would be well within his rights to advise the Queen not to sign such a bill into law.Were Johnson to seek to remain after  days without calling an election, he would be breaking the law, and it would then be for the courts, not the Queen, to intervene.It is certainly possible in theory that the sovereign could be called upon to choose between two rival claims to form a government. However, this would be regarded as highly political and has not been done since .In reality, it is far more likely that the numbers in Parliament will tell us who does or does not have a majority, and that a general election will be called before getting the Queen involved.We all know what this is really about, though. The vote for Brexit was always destined to bring us to a constitutional crisis. It was the first moment in our country’s long and proud history when a majority of people outside of Parliament asked for something that a majority of people inside Parliament did not want to give.The right way through this mess is not to drag the Queen into politics but to deliver on the decision that was made by the British people more than three years ago.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris global britain remainers brexit pulling up drawbridge
story: Boris’s announcement that — once we’ve left — the UK will welcome the best and brightest science minds from around the world is a real commitment to a truly Global Britain.It marks an end to the absurd state of affairs in which we had an open door to anybody born in the EU, regardless of their talents, and were effectively forced to slam another door in the face of those who have shown themselves to be  leaders in their fields.There are still those who think that the vote to leave the EU was an  anti-immigrant vote. It wasn’t. It was a vote to take back control.And as we look towards our departure, this Government must deliver an open immigration system that welcomes those who will  contribute to the economy and  le of our great country.With a say on who comes in — and who doesn’t — we’ll be able to ensure our public services are ready for a population increase and that the supply of houses goes up as quickly as it needs to.Don’t believe the doomsayers. Once we’re free of Brussels’ grip this country can take its place back at the very top of the world. A magnet for hard-working, talented people, who can take our already successful businesses to the next level.It’s another clear reason why, no matter how messy our departure sometimes seems, and how long it is taking…Britain is still better off out.JUST when you thought Project Fear was dead, here comes the BBC to stick it on le support.We’ve had such a constant barrage of scare stories about a clean break Brexit that anybody who believed them all would have run for the hills with a decade’s worth of spam and a shotgun.This week  there have been panicked predictions of rationing and cattle culls and warnings from US economist Larry Summers — who some see as one of the architects of the  financial crisis — that we’re a “desperate” nation which can’t hope for a decent US trade deal.Given rather less fanfare by Auntie was a letter from Republican Senators pledging to deliver just that.Some comfort is that nobody’s buying it any more.The public is rapidly losing faith in the Beeb.FINALLY, it’s back.The Premier League promises to be better than ever — and this season will see the added drama of VAR. title: binge drinking mum baby breastfeeding new zealand
story: Little Sapphire Williams, from Ahipara, New Zealand, died on January , , and was found with six times the legal blood alcohol limit in her system.A recent coroner’s reports in to her tragic death did not find a direct cause of death but found that booze intoxication and a dangerous sleeping environment were factors in her passing.Her mum admitted to authorities that she drank  bourbon and cokes at her cousin’s house the day before her daughter’s death.The alcohol in the blood from Sapphire’s heart was found at have  milligrams per  millilitres of blood – six times the legal limit for a driver in New Zealand.Baffled toxicologists performed the test a second time but the results were the same both times, the New Zealand Herald reports.Coroner Debra Bell believes Sapphires death could have been prevented.She said: “Unfortunately, her mother chose to drink a large quantity of alcohol and subsequently at a later stage chose to breastfeed her.“ accepts the alcohol in Sapphires blood must have come from her consumption of alcohol. Sapphires mothers actions highlight what has been well documented alcohol can pass to a child via breast milk.”Investigators found no suspicious circumstances at the family of nine’s home, it has been reported.According to the post-mortem report, possible causes of death included acute alcohol intoxication, dangerous sleeping environment, prematurity, possible septicaemia and suffocation.The baby and her twin sister Honey were born prematurely at  weeks in .However, Sapphire had missed prescribed doses of vitamin C and Iron, which had been left at the family’s old house, shortly before her death.Her mother normally used formula milk to feed the child but would breastfeed to calm the baby down as she waited for the bottle to cool.Good news mums, you can drink alcohol when breastfeeding - but only in moderation.The NHS advise that mums have no more than two units of alcohol, twice-a-week.To put that into context, one unit equates to a ml shot, half a pint of beer, or a ml glass of wine.Which means one double spirit measure, a pint or a largeglass of wine is your limit for the day.Regularly drinking more than two units per day can affect your babys development, according to some studies, meaning its just not worth the risk.And boozing parents should make sure theres a sober adult on-hand to care for young kids.Never share a bed or a sofa with your babyyouve had a drink, as this can increase the risk of sudden infant death syndrome .

title: yousef makki mum teens moonwalked past trial
story: Yousef Makki, , was kned in the heart in leafy Hale Barns, Cheshire - an area popular with Man United footballers - in an alleged drug deal robbery gone wrong.But his mum Debbie revealed her heartbreak after two middle class teens were cleared of stabbing Yousef.A boy, , known as Boy A admitted to stabbing the Manchester Grammar School pupil in March but was cleared of murder and manslaughter. A negative result is also a result.“In order for a missile to fly, you need to test all its components: engines, fuel - everything.”He forecast the Russian authorities would give scant detail of the incident.Only those who participated could say what went wrong. Yet no one will name all the reasons,” he said.“This requires an investigation.“It is not known what kind of explosion, the volume, or scale. There is no such information yet. ”One local named Sergey Dolgushin from Severodvinsk said: “Uusuallythe authorities say that everything is okay it means the exact opposite.“This is exactly how they were lying to people at Chernobyl.”Deep secrecy has surrounded tests and designs of the Zircon, which Putin claims is unmatched by any Western missile.In May it was reported that trials launching the missile from a naval vessel would be started later in .Previously it is believed that the shark-nosed Zircon has been tested at least five times from land-based sites, and is capable of a speed of . miles per second.In June  the missile reached eight times the speed of sound, according to reports.The Royal Navy’s Sea Ceptor surface-to-air missile is reportedly only capable of intercepting targets flying up to Mach .Hypersonic cruise missile Zircon is designed to be used against ships or land-based targets, and to enter production in , commencing service the following year.In April, Dmitry Kiselyov, presenter of Russia’s main weekly TV news show Vesti Nedeli, showed on screen a map of the US identying targets he claimed Moscow would want to hit in a nuclear war. Kiselyov, seen as a top Putin propagandist, said the Zircon missile could hit the targets in less than five minutes.Putin warned this year that the West is seeking to steal secrets relating to Zircon and other state-of-the-art Russian weapons such as the Avangard.He told his FSB counter-intelligence service:  That means that your work should become even more effective.Explosions have also been reported at the Russian arms depot in Achinsk where five people are said to have been injured.Interfax News says people living close to the base were evacuated due to exploding shells.The latest blast comes four days after another series of blasts killed one and injured a further .

title: dog owner slammed groomers after chopped part poodles tongue off during clipping
story: Lee Taiseng took the white poodle puppy named Mario for a shampoo and trim at the pet salon in Bukit Batok, Singapore.But later that day, the manager called Lee to confess that the groomers scissors had caused a small slit in Marios tongue, which was bleeding.Lee and his partner were horried when they arrived at the vets to find part of Marios tongue dangling off.Tragically, vets decided to amputate the injured muscle, which has left the pooch with part of his tongue missing for the rest of his le.Lee slammed the Paws Chu Kang grooming salon and claimed he rejected their offer of compensation of around £ for the injury.Instead, the couple asked for a letimes supply of food, grooming and doggy supplements - which the salon has refused.Lee said: Can you imagine the shock and horror we felt when we found out the slit was actually a cut that extended three-quarters diagonally through his tongue We had no idea how long Mario was left bleeding for - and they admitted that they did not inform me immediately after the incident happened.According to the vet, Marios tongue could have been savedthey had acted responsibly enough to rush Mario to the vet as soon as possible.Due to the extended duration of inaction [estimated to be for a few hours], the dangling portion of the tongue had to be amputated, leaving Mario [with] a shorter tongue.It was a painful recovery for Mario, who had to be syringe and spoon-fed until he learned how to lick up his food and water with a shortened tongue.Lee said that the grooming salon covered the vets fees, but the owners have since been locked in a dispute about compensation.The owners of the Paws Chu Kang salon apologised for the injury and said the employee who accidentally snipped Marios tongue had since left the job.They told local media that they had offered compensation of , Singaporean dollars - which had been rejected by the couple.Paws Chu Kang said in a statement: I would like to express my sincerest apologies to Mr Lee and Mrs Lee on what had happened to Mario during his grooming session with one of my ex-staff.The previous employee we hired, and who committed the mistake is a licensed and experienced groomer with more than five years experience in the grooming industry.The groomer is no longer employed with us.As a dog owner myself, I understand how terried and painful Mario must have felt during the incident.Thus, I have been following up with Mrs Leeresponsibly and rendered all assistance within my capability from the day this incident occurred.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chase bank cancels credit card debt canada
story: Customers using the Amazon.ca Rewards Visa and the Marriott Rewards Premier Visa were elated to find their credit card balance had been wiped clean, saving Canadian customers millions.The US bank, part of the New York based JPMorgan Chase  Co., closed all credit card accounts in the country in March .However on Thursday, customers were pleasantly surprised to have been told the outstanding debt is now cancelled.Maria Martinez, vice president of communications for Chase Card Services, said in a statement: Chase made the decision to exit the Canadian credit card market.As part of that exit, all credit card accounts were closed on or before March . A further business decision has been made to forgive all outstanding balances in order to complete the exit.Chase declined to say how much debt was forgiven or how many customers were affected.Douglas Turner, a -year-old trucker living in Coe Hill, Ontario, was delighted to learn the bank had wiped clean his £,debt.He told CBC News: “I was sort of over the moon all last night, with a smile on my face. I couldn’t believe it.Its crazy. This stuff doesnt happen with credit cards. Credit cards are horror stories.The -year-old trucker also told CBC that his most recent payment on the account would also be reimbursed.Paul Adamson, a -year-old south-western Ontario resident, immediately phoned the bank when he saw the £,balance on one of his credit cards had been wiped clean.Adamson told the Global News: She said: Actually, you owe no balance.’She added: I was a little confused and kind of sceptical at her response. I was stunned, I’ll be honest. I just said: ‘Hey, here’s one more thing we don’t need to worry about.’”Christine Langlois, of Montreal, told CBC she stopped making payments on her card five years ago.A -year-old university student, she said: Its kind of like Im being rewarded for my irresponsibility.

title: great gran aged 90 crack dealer
story: Enid Malcolm collected cash from drug addicts and acted as a lookout, JPs heard.Magistrates heard problems began in  after Enid’s husband Polones died.Her son, cousin and grandson were said to be involved in drugs.Cop raids found crack cocaine, knives and cash at the property.Vivien Sedgley, for the council, said: “She simply must know what is going on.”Enid shook her head and tutted loudly at the claims.Her solicitor Nigel Hallchurch said: “There are just vague allegations with no evidence.”The court heard Enid refused to move.Granting a three-month closure order, chairman of the bench Angela Sharpe said: “There is enough compelling evidence a person has engaged in disorder and criminal activity at the property.This does not infer in any way that Mrs Malcolm was involved in any criminal activity.”The pensioner was given three hours to collect belongings before the house was boarded up.

title: mum baby eczema healed cream high street
story: At just three months old, Archie McGford suffered intense bleeding and cracked skin, on his face, elbows, back and knees.Paige McGford, , began to fear leaving her house in case people would think he was being abused,Doctors told her Archie would grow out of it, prescribing steroid cream for this dry skin.Four months on, Archie was still not relieved of his symptoms.Paige told MailOnline: I was shocked because there was no way Archies condition could be described as just dry skinShe decided to try high street creams as it was so upsetting seeing my baby in such a state.But after a recommendation from a pal, she bought the £. cream Baby Kingdom Collection and was amazed at the incredible results.She added: At best, I thought it may take a few weeks to have an effect, but the Baby Kingdom cream cleared it up in just two days which was just incredible and such a relief.Paige is now encouraging other parents to find ways to help their children, evendoctors say otherwise.The condition affects people of all ages, but is typically diagnosed in children.Many young sufferers will grow out of their condition as they get older.But, in many cases, flare ups in adulthood end up coming back to haunt people.In the UK, one in five children are diagnosed with eczema, while one in  adults live with the condition.

title: orangutan undergoes op appendix
story: Ben, a -year-old male orangutan, had to have an emergency appendectomy performed by surgeons after they noticed that the ape appeared lethargic, uncomfortable and uninterested in his food.After medical treatments did not cure the animal, Ben, who is housed at Brookfield Zoo, in Chicago, underwent an extensive examination.He had blood tests, ultrasounds, CAT scans and was diagnosed with peritonitis, an inflammation of the peritoneum, and appendicitis, an inflammation of the appendix.After determining his diagnosis,  members of veterinary staff immediately started the five-hour long operation and removed the ruptured appendix without any complications.A recheck examination weeks later confirmed Ben’s problems were fully resolved and that the surgical incision had fully healed.Dr Eric Yang, a general surgeon who has performed this procedure on humans, said: “The opportunity to help Ben was unique, similar to operating on a child, except that Ben is a  pound orangutan!“We were impressed with the level of care, concern, and professionalism on display by the zoo’s team.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: giant panda rare twins birth belgium
story: Hao Hao, their mother, was inseminated in April and gave birth to the tiny pair on Thursday, with each being born a few hours apart.Both cubs - a boy and girl - were born at the Pairi Daiza Zoo in Belgium and are being bottle fed to let their mum rest.The babies, described as “pink shrimp”, are hairless, pink and  th the size of their mother when they are born.They will be watched around the clock to ensure their survival and could be alternately place in an incubator.Eric Domb, the president and founder of Pairi Daiza, said: “This double birth is wonderful news for this extraordinary species that is still threatened today.”Hao Hao was loaned to the park by China in , and gave birth to a male cub three years ago.China established an international program for the conservation of giant pandas, according to the zoo.The animals’ status was changed from endangered to vulnerable by the International Union for Conservation of Nature in . Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn labour unfit government
story: But Labour are still lumbered with their dismal, discredited chief.Even as Jeremy Corbyn sinks deeper in the mire of unpopularity, his party makes no real attempt to dump him.Instead of taking action, Corbyn’s detractors just carp and criticise from the sidelines.Last week’s poor result in the Brecon and Radnorshire by-election, where the Labour candidate gained just five per cent of the vote, led to a new wave of condemnation.Former Northern Ireland Secretary Lord Hain said that Labours performance at Brecon had been truly dreadful, yet our current leadership carries on regardless towards disaster.Even more savage was another former Cabinet Minister Alan Johnson, one of the most respected Labour moderates, who said that practically anyone would be better in the job.Jeremy Corbyn is not just pious and sanctimonious, he’s useless at leading, which is why he has people around him to do his shoelaces and pull his strings, claimed Johnson.As a former Labour activist who spent a decade working alongside Corbyn in his Islington North constituency, I agree with everything Johnson says.Having observed him at close quarters during the years when he was a backbench rebel, I now find the idea of Corbyn as Prime Minister both laughable and terrying.Profoundly unfit for the highest office, he is a toxic ideological extremist without a clue about how to govern Britain.Having poisoned his own party, he would wreck our country toohe came near to power.But what makes me despair is the timidity of sensible Labour folk, who regard Corbyn with contempt yet are still willing to march under his banner.They proclaim that they think he is a disaster, but they allow him to remain in place.This pathetic ineffectuality was captured by Yvette Cooper, widely regarded as possible alternative leader, who bleated to the BBC at the weekend that there is a real concern we don’t look like enough of a broad church at the moment.What a gross understatement.In fact, the Labour Party is in the grip of hardline, quasi-Marxist, anti-Semitic personality cult.But apart from wringing their hands, the likes of Ms Cooper do nothing about it.If Labour is to have a future, the moderates have to get off their knees and start to challenge Corbyn properly.They should be inspired by the words of the great former leader Hugh Gaitskell, a passionate centrist, who famously told the  conference — where the left had prevailed — that he would fight, fight and fight again to bring back sanity and honesty and dignity to the party I love.The moderates need that kind of resolution today, but they show precious little sign of it.They are not only cowardly, but also hypocritical.They send their angry tweets and whine to the broadcasters, but, by campaigning for Labour, they are still working for Corbyn to be Prime Minister.If, as appears likely, a General Election is called soon, the so-called moderates will all be out canvassing in their constituencies for theof a Corbyn-led Government.That reality makes all their denunciations of him completely meaningless.Effectively, the moderates are Corbyn enablers and agents of his extremism.Rather than serve as doormats, they should take a lesson from the Tories, who have long been ruthless about dumping their leaders.Neville Chamberlain, Anthony Eden, Ted Heath, Iain Duncan-Smith, and even Margaret Thatcher were all clinically dispatched once they were deemed to be ineffective or unpopular.The same ruthlessness with personnel could be seen in the way Boris Johnson reconstructed his Cabinet last month as he sacked  ministers in his night of the blond knives, including even the Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt.In contrast, Labour has always been pathetically soft about butchery.In the whole of the party’s -year history, only one leader has ever been forced out against his will and that, ironically, was Tony Blair, by far Labour’s greatest election winner.All the rest chose when to go, even the poor ones like Neil Kinnock, Michael Foot and the s pacist George Lansbury.Today, there are plenty of steps that the moderates could take to crank up the pressure on Corbyn.They could push for another vote of no confidence in him. They could resign the Labour whip in the Commons. They could boycott his appearances at Prime Ministers Questions and other statements.But, as Labour slides towards catastrophe, they have done none of this.What explains their inaction  Part of the answer is fear of the Corbyn machine, especially his supporters’ powerful pressure group Momentum, which is notorious for its intolerance.In fact, though there has been a recent decline in Labour membership, Corbyn backers still make the majority of activists.Any Labour MP who speaks out against Corbyn therefore risks deselection. For the sake of their Parliamentary careers, most of them keep quiet.But there are also deeper factors at work.One is mainstream Labour’s horror at any supposed betrayal of the socialist cause.This is partly because Labour is such a tribal movement, as shown in the ferocious anger generated in  by Ramsay MacDonald’s decision to break with the party by forming a National Government with the despised Tories.Since then treachery is regarded as the greatest sin, far worse than incompetence or unpopularity.This trait particularly insulates Corbyn, who, for all his spectacular failings, is still regarded by the majority of the membership as an authentic socialist.There is also a deep streak of sentimentality in Labour, which stems from the party’s origins in the trade union movement.In this mindset of supposed compassion, sacking people is what the bosses do, not the workers.When the nondescript Clement Attlee was surprisingly elected Labour leader in , supporters of his rival Herbert Morrison tried to comfort him by saying Attlee’s spell at the top would be short-lived.Morrison was having none of it.The party, he said, was sentimental and having once made a man leader, would stick to him.He was right. Attlee was still in post  years later.Sentimentality explains why so many anti-leadership plots are botched.I saw this for myself working as a Labour researcher at Westminster in the late s and early s, when there were hidden manoeuvres against Kinnock.But they all came to nothing because the plotters lacked the determination to finish the job.The same was true during Gordon Brown’s woeful premiership, when conspirators abandoned the battle when the moment came to strike.More interested in dogma than office, the Labour party lacks the unsparing instinct for power that infuses the Tories, which helps to explain why the Conservatives have been in Government for twice as long. Since  , the Tories have been in office for  years and Labour for just .The absence of hard ambition means that socialists are willing to put up with a dud like Corbyn, while they mouth their slogans and wave the red flag.

title: brussels chiefs want showdown with boris but order him to keep the backstop first if he wants better deal before october 31
story: The European Commission said the Withdrawal Agreement was “not up for negotiation” in a statement today.“And of course we are willing to talk and engage with Prime Minister Johnson.”The PM has so far refused to hold talks with EU chiefs and will not compromise on his stance against Theresa May’s hated deal.He has previously warned thatthe EU dont budge on getting rid of the backstop, it will be their choice to push Britain out of the bloc without an agreement by October .The backstop, which would come into playa future trading arrangement falls short of keeping the border open, has been the main stumbling block on Brexit negotiations.However, Andreeva said it was not the Commission’s “business” to play a “blame game”.She added: “Our business is to prepare for a no deal.“Both sides negotiated with the very best intentions and the very best efforts. The outcome on the table is the best deal possible and I dont think that there is any fault or blame to be looked for in this.“We just simply expect the UK to live up to its commitment to avoiding a hard border while protecting Irelands place in the internal market.”However, despite Andreeva saying the EU was open to meeting Boris, the bloc’s chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said there will be no new deal.But Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay called on EU leaders to give Barnier the mandate to re-broker an agreement, otherwise no-deal is coming down the tracks.Mr Barnier needs to urge EU leaders to consider thisthey too want an agreement, to enable him to negotiate in a way that finds common ground with the UK. Otherwise, No Deal is coming down the tracks, Barclay wrote in the Mail on Sunday.It is our firm view that Irish border issues should be dealt with in talks on the future agreement between the UK and the EU -- where they should always have been -- and were ready to negotiate in good faith on this basis.The backstop, which would come into playa future trading arrangement falls short of keeping the border open, has been the main stumbling block in the Brexit talks and one of the reasons why Britains parliament rejected the deal three times.Johnson has vowed to get rid of the backstop and the new government has taken a hard line with the EU, saying it was turbo-boosting preparations for a no-deal Brexitthe bloc fails to agree alternative arrangements for the border.Barclay said officials were working on those arrangements.We have already started work across Whitehall to find the solutions, and they can and will be found, in the context of the free trade agreement we will negotiate with the EU after October , he wrote.

title: dominic raab travels 21309 miles in just three days in mammoth brexit trade deal blitz
story: The Foreign Secretary was sent across the world by Boris Johnson to broker new trade deals with the US, Canada and Mexico on a three-day whistle-stop tour.On Tuesday, Raab flew into Toronto to meet foreign affairs minister Chrystia Freeland, before jetting off for a crucial summit with President Donald Trump in Washington and finally arriving in Mexico City later today.Boris has ramped up efforts to strike new ambitious relationships with global partners as the UK prepares for its orce from EU on October .The PM has long spoken of the opportunities away from the bloc with nations like the US and Australia lined up for bonanza trade deals.On the first day of Raabs trans-Atlantic charm offensive, he told reporters that he wanted to take Canada and the UKs relationship to the “next level”.He said: “Were going to remain and we hope to be good European neighbours, partners and friends in the future but we do want to grasp those global opportunities and we want to expand our horizons and raise our level of ambitions in the world.”After Toronto, Raab zoomed over to the White House to meet with President Trump and key officials including, Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.Wednesdays meeting was a huge success for No with the President again reaffirming his “huge appetite” for a trade deal with Britain after Brexit.Pompeo offered another boost for Boris, when he said: “We support the United Kingdom’s sovereign choice, however Brexit ultimately shakes out.“And we’ll be on the doorstep, pen in hand, ready to sign a new free trade agreement at the earliest possible time.”Raab’s fast and furious tour ends today with a visit to Mexico City where he believes economic links between our two nations will be a “win-win”.He said: “The UK is excited to be working with our Mexican friends to develop a win-win relationship.“There are huge opportunities to boost two-way trade, create jobs, tackle poverty and inequality, and address key Mexican priorities such as strengthening transparency and reducing corruption.”Boris is desperate for Britain to make new trade links as the government prepares for a No Deal scenario with Brussels chiefs.The PM has warned Tory rebels are EU negotiators that we will be leaving the bloke “do or die” by Halloween.Raabs first two weeks as Foreign Secretary have been jam-packed - meeting  ministers and travelling to Thailand in his first few days in the job.Back in Westminster the PM met with the Prime Minister of Estonia and Juri Ratas and the King Abdullah II of Jordan to hold Brexit trade talks of his own.But while Johnson and Raab look to le after the EU – an ex-Supreme Court judge said Tory Remainers can still block a No Deal Brexit.Lord Sumption, one of Britain’s top legal minds, insists they would have to choose between the “long shots” of rushing through a law against it or toppling Boris Johnson and forming an interim Government.He backed our story that the PM has the power to call an election for after the Halloween Brexit datehe loses a confidence vote so could force it through anyway.He told the BBC: There are really only two ways in which Parliament could stop a No Deal Brexit on that scenario.One option would be for MPs to pass an emergency law demanding the Government revoke Article  – meaning Britain no longer leaves the UK at all – unless a deal was agreed by a particular date.The other would be that in the fortnight after a successful no confidence vote, an interim government is formed that would either ask for another extension from Brussels or hold a second referendum.“The Prime Minister has been very much ‘in your face’ in saying that he is heading for No Deal.”

title: 1950s bikini dancers party soho sunset jazz club
story: The incredible images dating from  show the bustling nightle in Sohos Sunset Club - known for its live jazz music which played until  am.Other striking shots show an interracial couple kissing in the corner, club-goers dancing the night away and musicians playing into the early hours of the morning.At a time when immigrants from the Caribbean faced intense discrimination in Britain, pictures from the Soho jazz club seem to depict a happy co-existence.Racism in the s was re, culminating with the Notting Hill race riots where African and Caribbean migrants faced violent attacks across the capital.However, Londons Soho area acted as a meeting place for many to appreciate and enjoy jazz and calypso music.The remarkable photos were taken at the Sunset Club in London’s Carnaby Street in  and were recently discovered by Topfoto in their extensive archives. Carnaby Street in Londons Soho district has been the site of many iconic nightclubs - including the Blue Lagoon Club in the s and the Sunset Club in the s.They were often run for and by the black community, with calypso and jazz music dominating the performances.Sunset Club was known for being a racially mixed club where music was played until seven in the morning.American GIs were regular customers, as they were in many London clubs in the s and s following the Second World War.Caribbean music sat at the very heart of the club - and the Russ Henderson Steel Band, the first steel band in Britain formed in , played their first gig there.Russ Henderson said: Evenyoud never met a Jamaican or an African, you got together in London.And Soho was the place in those days, particularly the Sunset Club in Carnaby Street, where jazz played until seven in the morning.That was where the musicians went when the other clubs closed: West Indians and Africans along with the Chris Barbers and the Humphrey Lyttletons.Racially, it was totally mixed.There was no such thing as a black clientele then.”According to Duke Vin, the first man to bring sound systems ton the UK, by  the Sunset Club was one of the five main Caribbean music clubs in London, along with the Contemporanean in Mayfair and Club .The proprietor of the Sunset Club, Gustavus Alexander Leslie, filed for bankruptcy in December .

title: brian reade no sugar coating
story: NewsopinionBrian Reade: No sugar-coating... the Queen should tell Johnson ‘you’re fired’I’m not Her Majesty’s biggest fan, butshe sees her authority questioned and her country at war, whos to say she won’t hatch her own cunning plan ShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  AUG NewsopinionPrime Minister Boris Johnson "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBookies are taking bets on the first thing Boris Johnson’s government will ration after a no-deal Brexit. I’m thinking of putting a tenner on admissions of guilt, because they’re guaranteed to be thinner than the gruel most of the poor will have to eat when food prices rocket. Or answers to the question, “how did we end up being driven over a clf by a man described as ‘a mentalist’ and a ‘career psychopath’ who runs a ‘reign of terror’ at the heart of government ”Words used by Tories who’ve worked with the man now referred to as “ Boris Johnson’s brain ”, his chief of staff Dominic Cummings . You’ve seen him, even though you’re not supposed to as he prides himself on working in the shadows. He’s the one who looks like a constipated Gollum wearing a T-shirt he’s nicked off a teenage intern.Someone bullied at school for being an uppity nerd who spent his adult le in a bedsit plotting how to detonate a bomb at his classmates’ reunion.    The Leave mastermind who won the referendum vote by training people to shout “take back control”, “let’s give £m a week to the NHS” and “the dirty Turks will take your jobs”. Although the mastermind had no idea what to do once the vote had been won, which is why the hapless Leave crew have parachuted him back in and he’s now training them to shout, “politicians don’t get to choose which votes they respect”. Good news though. The elitist-hating Oxford graduate, who’s married to a baronet’s daughter, has come up with a cunning plan which involves Johnson refusing to resign after losing a no-confidence vote in the Commons and squatting in Downing Street until a no-deal Brexit is done. And although constitutional experts say the Queen could “dispense with his services”, Cummings is betting there’s no chance of that because she never interferes in politics.    Like a crinoline toilet roll doll, she merely sits there for decoration. But can he be sure  I’m not the Queen’s biggest fan, butshe sees her authority questioned and her country at war, who’s to say she won’t hatch her own cunning plan One that smacks down two-bit opportunists such as Johnson and Cummings and strikes back at hardened Republicans like me who see the royals as pointless, palace-dwelling parasites.

Marcus Stewart, , from Coventry, was arrested by an armed policeman on the beach after a head-on crash on Marbella’s famous Golden Mile with a car carrying an -day-old baby. Footage of the arrest shows Stewart being frogmarched away from the sand barefoot in just a pair of shorts, an officer walking behind him with his gun in his hand. Spanish state prosecutors have charged Stewart with one count of reckless driving, nine counts of wounding and one count of damage.  Prosecutors are also seeking just over £, in compensation for the nine people injured in the May ,  incident. They include the pedestrians hurt outside the Ocean Club in Puerto Banus and others injured when the Audi Q Stewart was in crashed after a police chase. No charges have been brought against a second Brit held in the drama, named at the time as Liam O’Neill, , from Walsgrave near Coventry, and identied by police as a passenger in the Audi. He is no longer a suspect. Stewart is accused in a nine-page indictment of getting behind the wheel despite taking cocaine and being over the Spanish drink-drive limit. Prosecutors say he got in the Audi belonging to a friend after a fight as he left the Ocean Club and “conscious of the danger and with absolute contempt for the lives of pedestrians, accelerated at great speed on a walkway against people who were leaving the establishment.”  One of his alleged victims was hit from behind before Stewart “sparked panic among people there, forcing them to flee to avoid being run over because there was nowhere for them to take cover” according to the prosecution document. Stewart was held a couple of miles away after a crash at the end of a high-speed police chase which ended with him smashing head-on into a Skoda. The days-old baby travelling with her mum and dad in the other vehicle survived unharmed but the family’s pet Yorkshire Terrier called Nina died. Stewart was found to be twice over the Spanish drink-drive limit when he was breathalysed.Cocaine was also detected in his bloodstream during tests, according to police. Marbella’s then-mayor Jose Bernal said in the aftermath of the drama the incident was sparked by an altercation at the Ocean Club after an annual champagne party there attended by the two suspects. He was forced to make a defence of the area at a press conference by insisting “Marbella is a safe place and when isolated incidents like this occur, the emergency services and forces of law and order have shown they act immediately and efficiently.” He branded the two Brits involved as two drunks on drugs who had a fight in a club got in a car and ended up running over three people who thankfully survived.

title: chef blasts customer unannounced allergies
story: NewsMichelin star chef blasted for publicly shaming diner with food allergiesEXCLUSIVE: The diner was apparently allergic to beans, gluten, dairy, garlic, onion, citrus and tomatoesShareCommentsByRosaleen Fenton:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsChez Bruce head chef Matt Christmas cooked up a storm online after complaining about the unknown diner "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA top chef at a Michelin star restaurant has been criticised over a “stupid” tweet about a guest who suffered from multiple allergies.Chez Bruce head chef Matt Christmas cooked up a storm online after complaining about the unknown diner.In a now deleted post on his personal Twitter account, the chef moaned: “Surely no restaurant in the country could deal with this unannounced list of ‘ allergies ’ professionally mid-service.“Let us know in advance people, this is a pretty prohibitive list, one might assume you want it to be a problem.” One user responded: “Not sureI feel more sorry for you guys in the kitchen or the person having all these allergies..” to which the chef sarcastically replied: “‘Allergies’ !!” But his post has now been removed after allergy sufferers accused the chef of publicly shaming the guest.Do you have multiple allergies  Email webnews@mirror Riz Wahid, , whose son died after eating pasta on holiday dubbed the tweet by the top chef stupid. Seven-year-old Cameron Wahid, of East Grinstead, West Sussex, went into anaphylactic shock after having spaghetti containing dairy products on a family holiday in Sorrento, Italy, in . Dad Riz, who now lives in Dubai, said: To tweet about what someone  has is totally unecessary. In terms of the point that heaposs asking people to tell them beforehand, I get that. But then to turn it into a bit of mockery on Twitter, itaposs just uncalled for. The words he chose could have been a lot more sophisticated. He added: Itaposs a stupid tweet, itaposs a naive tweet. Obviously I think he needs to sit down with some people who go through very hard times or people with allergies so he understands their le.  And Julianne Ponan, , whose severe allergies inspired her to set up Creative Nature Superfoods, which offers products free from additives, nuts and seeds, slammed the chef. She said: You canapost change your allergies. I think itaposs awful that someone would so dismissive and publicly shame someone over their intolerances. I already feel like an inconvenience when I have to inform restaurants about my multiple allergies, I donapost expect the chef to then tweet about it.  Especially when youaposre going out for a really nice restaurant, they should be able to accommodate you without making a fuss about it on social media. On Twitter, the official account for Chez Bruce, in Wandsworth, southwest London, added: “One has sympathies for guests with allergies food intolerances. “But handing us a list like this without prior notice is hardly the most sensible way of ensuring that we are able to do our best to cater for them. “Good luck with that in most other restaurants!”  In response to the chefaposs post, Andrew Stevenson tweeted: “While I sympathise with people with real allergies and intolerances, this looks like silly faddiness and just trying to make your le dficult. “And I find it dficult to believe that theyaposre allergic to tomatoes, but are ok with potatoes and aubergines.”And a Twitter account run for posh pub Abbot’s Elm, in Abbots Ripton, Cambridegshire, scathingly dubbed it “attention seeking.”But on Twitter, Julie Andrews added: As someone with multiple GENUINE le threatening food allergiesthis is worrying. And Freya said: This looks like a list from someone who might be struggling with an inflammatory bowel condition. While some advance notice should absolutely be given it’s a real shame to see so much mockery and lack of understanding in the comments.  Holborn Dining Roomaposs executive chef Calum Franklin said diners needed to ring ahead so kitchens could prepare. He said: I think my major problem with this is the unannounced part of it. “If you have this many allergies honestly it must be really c*** and I do really feel sorry for you but help restaurants out with a bit of pre warning and they will look after you so well. “Just dropping it on the night causes havoc in kitchens, which are usually set up to deal with a couple of allergies and options but this many makes things complicated and affects the experience of everyone around you as chefs scramble around trying to create a new menu for you. If you are then rude to the staff whilst they are trying to accommodate these requests in the middle of a full service thataposs pretty inconsiderate and you need to do a bit of one on one mirror time in the morning. “We often get emails from guests who have lists longer than this and do you know what, we enjoy planning a menu for them. “Itaposs a challenge and we want to make sure they feel very well looked after but thataposs only possible with a bit of notice.”    After removing his tweets this morning, Mr Christmas added: Deleted my allergy tweet. For the record I just wished to highlight the benefit of letting restaurants know in advance of any dietary requirements, that way we can better look after you on the day with more options. I have the utmost respect for diners with genuine allergies. Also, when I said anyone would struggle to deal with it professionally, I meant with the standards of hospitality that we endeavour to deliver to every guest, in no way was it a reference to the preparation of the food.

story: NewsGran, , evicted from home of  years used as crack den vows to sleep at bus stopEnid Malcolm claims she had no part in the drug dealing operation a her home in Highfields, Leicestershire, and isnt happy with the council home shes been offered insteadShareByDan MartinKelly-Ann Mills:,  AUG NewsEnid Malcolm says she didnt know about the drugs "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA great grandmother evicted from her home of nearly  years because it was being used as a crack house, has said sheaposll apossleep in a bus shelterapos. Enid Malcolmaposs home was closed by the courts for three month in a bid to stop the violence, disorder and nuisance affecting her neighbours in Leicester. Compelling evidence said the house was being used to deal class A drugs and Leicester City Council claimed Mrs Malcolm was aware of the drug dealing and was involved in it. The -year-old pensioner had lived and raised her family in the three-bedroom end terraced house, Leicestershire Live reports and she said sheaposd rather sleep in a bus shelter than the alternatives the council has offered. The council has offered Mrs Malcolm three alternative properties nearby and she has refused them all.  “I’ve seen it, she said. You wouldn’t put a dog in it. It’s a house but it’s not a home. “I’ll sleep in the bus stop tonight rather than let them put me in there. “I’m so upset. All I want to do is stay in my home where I lived with my husband. I’m too old for this. Theyaposve said Iaposm a drug dealer - that I wash crack.  I donapost even know what that means.Someoneaposs trying to stitch me up. Magistrates heard yesterday that problems began at the property in  after Mrs Malcolm’s husband Polones died. The council and the police said the problems were caused by her son George Malcolm, , and her cousin, Clyde Wallace, who were living with her. However the council also said Ms Malcolm was aware of the drug dealing and was involved in it. She denies this and sat in court shaking her head and loudly tutting as the evidence was presented. Vivienne Sedgley, representing, the council said: “The council’s case is that there is drug dealing taking place at the property. “The activities were taking place every day at all hours of the day and there is a serious problem in relation to the property. She said there had been reports of visitors to the house putting money through the letter box and being thrown drugs from a window.    She told the court: “You may wonder why no residents are here to give evidence. “They are afraidthey put their heads above the parapet that might make things very dficulty and uncomfortable. “Without a three month closure order the behaviour is simply going to continue.” The court was told police had executed three warrants at the property since , which led to the recovery of drugs, knives and large sums of cash. The warrants also led to a number of arrests and the conviction of Ms Malcolmaposs grandson Andre Alexis for possession with intent to supply. Mrs Malcolm was present on two of those occasions, though she was not arrested. The council argues she was part of the drug dealing operation and would accept the money to buy drugs, while ‘washing the crack’.    Ms Sedgley said the police believed she had acted as a look out for a drug deal in the street near her home and had once paid a refund to a buyer who was not satisfied with their purchase. Ms Sedgley said: “Mrs Malcolm has at least a level of awareness of what is going on. “She is a very capable woman who cares very much for her son George and her cousin Clyde who she says is like son to her. “She simply must know what is going on.” PC Mark Bailey, giving evidence, said the police initially treated her as a vulnerable person – as they would a domestic violence victim. Her solicitor Nigel Hallchurch said this was not true. He said: “There is nothing to suggest she had anything to do with what went on. “There are just vague allegations with no evidence.” He did not call his client to give evidence, but spoke about her statement to the police. He said: “She refers that she is not involved in any drug dealing, she doesn’t wash the crack, she hasn’t taken any money from anyone and she is not a look out.” Ms Sedgley told magistrates that to grant the closure order they needed only to be convinced that there was someone, not necessarily Mrs Malcolm, committing criminal activity at the house.

title: incredible new dog charity first
story: AdvertorialWhy incredible new dog charity - the first of its kind in UK - could be set for huge cash prizeThe Brainy Dogs scheme is a finalist in the th Birthday National Lottery AwardsShareByAlex LloydDave Masters:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG AdvertorialBrainy Dogs is run by the charity Headway Suffolk"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRESCUE dogs are being trained by vulnerable adults and teens to become canine companions for people with brain injuries. The Brainy Dogs scheme has created more than  le-changing new friendships to date, while giving offenders the chance to learn new skills. Now the National Lottery-funded project, the only one of its kind in the UK, is a finalist in the th Birthday National Lottery Awards, where you can help choose the winners. Brainy Dogs, which is run by the charity Headway Suffolk, is expanding to include one-to-one pet therapy sessions for clients who are not suitable for a companion dog and care home visits.  It is also offering people on probation, veterans, those with mental health problems and children excluded from school opportunities to train the animals. Headway Suffolk chief executive Helen Fairweather says: “Companion dogs can make a real dference to someone who is living with a neurological condition. “Their disabilities can often be hidden and may leave them with a personality change or dficulties that mean they lose friends and their families struggle to support them. “A dog can fill this void and provide help, comfort and confidence as they attempt to navigate le.” The charity boss came up with the unique scheme after reading a book about an assistance dog who aided the recovery of a brain-injured man and then watching a programme about prisoners in Australia training dogs. She realised that many of the people Headway works with could benefit from a similar furry friend. Many are not eligible to receive a dog from other charitable organisations as they are not regarded as having adequate need. Helen teamed up with Blue Cross Felixstowe and HMP Hollesley Bay in Suffolk for a one-year pilot in  and the concept has gone from strength to strength, receiving a £, grant from the National Lottery last year to expand. Brainy Dogs Coordinator Sophie Wellum-Mayes says training is inidual to each dog and client, taking around eight weeks.  Volunteer trainers gain work experience, le skills and improved confidence, along with improving the futures of the dogs and their new owners. She says: “The dogs calm clients in a way humans cannot. They do not judge and for many people, this is a rare feeling. “We have been told that the dogs are a leline, they have stopped a couple of clients from ending their lives. “They get people out into social networks, give them a sense of normality and something in common with others. There are similar emotional and confidence benefits for the trainers too.” The National Lottery Awards are an annual celebration of the UK’s best National Lottery-funded projects, with this year marking  years since the first draw. The winners will receive £, towards their extraordinary work and appear on a star-studded BBC One show in November. Voting is now open in five categories. To see the full list of finalists and cast your vote, visit lotterygoodcauses.org.uk awards by midnight on  August .

story: NewsMan subjected to humiliating prank at party found dead on the sofa the next dayMartyn Evans, , had a banana put up his nose, an eyebrow shaved off and bleach poured over his head at a party in Bishopsworth, Bristol, a court heardShareCommentsByGeoffrey Bennett:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsMartyn Evans was the victim of a humiliating prank"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man with learning dficulties subjected to a humiliating prank at a party was found dead on the sofa the next day. Four people have pleaded guilty to assaulting Martyn Evans.But their aposbullyingapos actions have not been linked to his death shortly afterward, reports Bristol Live.The -year-old was found dead on a sofa the day after the party in Bishopsworth in October last year. Video footage obtained from one of the party-goersapos phone showed how a semi-conscious Mr Evans had a banana put up his nose, an eyebrow shaved off and washing up liquid and bleach poured over his head.  His death, however, remains a mystery and has not been linked to his ill-treatment. The four charged also have learning dficulties and pleaded guilty to assault occasioning actual bodily harm. They are: Natasha McDonald, , of Lawrence Weston Patrick Brown, , of Bishopsworth Leanne Harford, , of Bishopsworth and Thomas Porter, , of Bishopsworth. Judge James Patrick handed them each an -month community order, with rehabilitation. You bullied him the night before he died and the death casts a long shadow, he said. No sentence will bring him back. Those who loved him will feel the aching void of his loss for the rest of their lives. The cause of death is not determined and there is no evidence you contributed to Martynaposs death. You are all, in your own way, vulnerable too. Martynaposs mum Alita, , who adopted him when he was aged seven months, said: I think what they did was disgusting. He was up for a joke but he wouldnapost do that to anyone. If he had woken up the next day he wouldnapost be happy, but at least heaposd be alive. A post-mortem concluded cause of death was unascertained and a coroneraposs inquest is due to be heard. James Haskell, prosecuting, said Martyn had learning dficulties and Aspergeraposs Syndrome. Mr Haskell said: Each defendant exploited his vulnerability for their own, immature entertainment. There is no evidence their actions caused or contributed to his death but their treatment of him was shameful. Mr Haskell said police retrieved footage on Hartfordaposs phone which showed how he was treated, and included attempts to wash off washing up liquid and bleach poured over his head. The male defendants made no comment to police. Mr Haskell said the female defendants explained what happened but blamed others. He told the court: The video has lots of laughing and joking and everybody thought it was amusing. It clearly wasnapost.
